questions.text: A 24 years primigravida presents in early labor. On abdominal examination, there is sub-umbilical flattening and on palpation, the fetus is in longitudinal lie, cephalic presentation with the head high and both sinciput and occiput felt at the same level. The fetal heart is auscultated at the flanks. What is the most likely abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Occipito-posterior

 

This is most likely an occipito-posterior position. 

 

The typical examination findings on abdominal examination in occipito-posterior are: 

 

  • Subumbilical flattening
  • Pelvic grip: Head is deflexed (Both sinciput and occiput felt at same level)
  • Auscultation: fetal heart heard at flanks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Occipito-transverse: On abdominal examination, the back will be on the lateral aspect and hence there will not be any subumbilical flattening. The fetal heart however may be better felt at the flanks. 

 

Option C: Face presentation: On abdominal exam, the typical finding is the sinciput and the back are on the same side (normally in flexed positions, the sinciput and back will be on opposite sides). A groove is felt between the back and the head. 

 

Option D: On abdominal exam, the head is unengaged, a groove is felt between the back and the occiput and the sinciput and the back are on the same side as in face presentation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occipito-Posterior Position

 

Risk Factors

 

  • Anthropoid pelvis
  • Android pelvis (less common)
  • Anterior placenta
  • CPD
  • Deflexed head

 

Diagnosis

 

Abdominal exam:

 

  • Sub-umbilical flattening
  • Pelvic grip: Head is deflexed (Both sinciput and occiput felt at same level)
  • Auscultation: fetal heart heard at flanks

 

Per vaginal exam

 

  • In a well flexed head, the anterior fontanelle cannot be palpated, but if you are able to palpate the fontanelle, that means the head is deflexed which is common in OP

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Long arc rotation by 135°
Short arc rotation by 135°
Long arc rotation by 45°
Short arc rotation by 45°

questions.text: A-23-year G2P1 presents in labor at 38 weeks with the fetus in left occipito-posterior position. She delivers a fetus by face to pubis. Which of the following mechanisms of labor would have occurred?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Short arc rotation by 45°

In Occipito posterior, there are 4 possibilities in mechanism of labor. This would also discuss the other Options

  1. Long arc rotation (Favourable mechanism): This is internal rotation anteriorly by 3/8th of a circle (135°), so that the occiput comes to lie anterior. This happens in a favourable pelvis with good contractions and good flexion of the head Unfavorable mechanisms:
  2. Short arc rotation: This is internal rotation posteriorly by 1/8th of a circle (45°) so that the occiput now lies posteriorly and head is delivered by face to pubes. Here the wider biparietal diameter distends the perineum instead of the smaller bitemporal diameter; and hence there are more perineal tears
  3. Deep Transverse Arrest:
    • Here long arc rotation starts but gets arrested after 45° I,e, when the saggital suture of fetus is in the interspinous diameter.
    • This happens commonly in android pelvis
    • Head is at zero station
    • Cervix is fully dilated
    • Good uterine contractions
    • Treatment
      • If primi/ obstructed labor: Cesarean
      • If multi (With no evidence of CPD): Vacuum can be tried
  4. Persistent Occipito-posterior:
    • Nothing happens here. The head remains as such
    • Management: Cesarean
    • Usually seen in CPD or deflexed head

Educational Objective:

  • Face to pubis delivery happens when the occiput (in Right or Left Occipito Posterior Position) undergoes short arc rotation i.e. rotation by 45 degree or 1/8th of a circle to become direct occipito posterior. 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: A-34-year G4P3 is referred from the primary center in view of prolonged labor. On examination, she is fully dilated. The head is at zero station and the head is in the right occipito transverse position. There is no caput and no moulding. Liquor is clear and FHR is 140 bpm. Contractions are 4 in 10 mins lasting for 40-45 seconds. The birth attendant who has accompanied the patient says she has been pushing since close to 2 hours What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vacuum

 

  • This is a case of deep transverse arrest (DTA) with no features of CPD/ Obstruction
  • There are no features of obstruction and the patient is G4P3, implying she has delivered 3 times earlier and this indirectly rules out a contracted pelvis
  • In DTA, if there is no obstruction and CPD is ruled out, vacuum can be tried as it has the feature of autorotation. Applying the vacuum at the flexion point will also aid in flexion of the head
  • In DTA, if there are features of obstruction or in a primigravida, emergency LSCS is the best wat to deliver

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency cesarean: This would have been the preferred management in a primigravida with similar findings or in a patient with findings of CPD or obstructed labor

 

Option B. Forceps: Forceps delivery (outlet or low) cannot be applied at stations above +2 or if there is no rotation. Forceps does not have the additional function of rotation which is seen in vacuum

 

Option D. Oxytocin: This is given when contactions are insufficient. In this scenario, the patient is getting good uterine contractions. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of Deep Transverse Arrest (DTA)

 

  • In Primi or Multi with evidence of CPD/ obstructed labor: Emergency cesarean
  • In Multigravida with no evidence of CPD/ Obstruction: Vacuum

 

There is no role of manual rotation or forceps in DTA

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: Which pelvis type is associated with occipito-posterior positions
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anthropoid

Anthropid pelvises are associated with Occipito Posterior positions

Educational Objective:

Pelvises and their common clinical associations

  • Anthropoid pelvis – Occipito-posterior/ deflexed head
  • Android pelvis – Obstructed labor
  • Platypelloid pelvis – Asynclitism
  • Gynecoid: Normal labor

choices.text: There is associated persistent deflexion in occipito-posterior position.
10% cases are associated with anthropoid-or android pelvis.
Incomplete forward rotation of occiput may cause deep transverse arrest.
Nonrotation of occiput may be seen if there is contracted pelvis

questions.text: The following statements are related to occipito-posterior except?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 10% cases are associated with anthropoid- or android pelvis. 

All the options given in the question are correct, except – option B

Let's Discuss all the Options

  • Option A: There is associated persistent deflexion in occipito-posterior position. This is a correct statement. Deflexion is a common association with ocipito-posterior positions
  • Option B: 10% cases are associated with anthropoid- or android pelvis. This is incorrect. More than 50% of all occipito-posterior positions are associated with an android or anthropoid pelvis. 
  • Option C: Incomplete forward rotation of occiput may cause deep transverse arrest. This is alos a true statement. Deep transverse arrest (DTA) occurs when the long arc rotation (Forward rotation) starts to happen but gets stuck in the transverse diameter of the pelvis
  • Option D: Nonrotation of occiput may be seen if there is contracted pelvis: This is a true statement. Persistent occipito posterior is seen when there is a contracted pelvis and it is an indication for cesarean section.

Educational Objective:

Anthropoid and Android pelvises are associated with > 50% of all occipito-posterior positions

 

ReF: Page no 299, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with an occiput posterior position. What is a potential maternal complaint commonly associated with it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Back pain

 

Explanation: An occiput posterior position is associated with severe back labor pain due to the fetal occiput pressing against the maternal sacrum.

 

This is the most common complaint associated with the occiput posterior position. The back of the baby's head pressing against the mother's sacrum can cause intense lower back pain, often referred to as "back labor." This pain can persist throughout labor and is often exacerbated during contractions.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option B: While abdominal pain is common during labor regardless of the fetal position, the OP position does not specifically cause more severe abdominal pain than other positions. However, labor might be longer and more painful overall due to the suboptimal alignment of the baby's head with the maternal pelvis.
  • Option C: Frequent urination is a common symptom of occipitoposterior
  • Option D: Shoulder pain or discomfort during pregnancy might be related to changes in posture, stress on the spine, or could be referred pain from gallbladder issues, which can be more common in pregnancy, but it's not a symptom commonly linked to fetal position in labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical features of Occipito posterior

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Backache
  • PROM
  • Frequency of micturition
  • Delayed engagement
  • Prolonged labor

 

Abdominal exam:

 

  • Sub-umbilical flattening
  • Pelvic grip: Head is deflexed (Both sinciput and occiput felt at same level)
  • Auscultation: fetal heart heard at flanks

 

 

  • Per vaginal exam
    • In a well flexed head, the anterior fontanelle cannot be palpated, but if you are able to palpate the fontanelle, that means the head is deflexed which is common in OP

 

Ref: Duttaâ€™s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 425
